input: All cats are animals. Fluffy is a cat. Is Fluffy an animal?
reasoning: If all cats are animals, and Fluffy is a cat, then Fluffy must be an animal.

input: If it rains, the ground gets wet. The ground is wet. Did it rain?
reasoning: The ground could be wet from other sources (sprinklers, snow melting, etc.). This is affirming the consequent fallacy.

input: All roses are flowers. Some flowers are red. Are all roses red?
reasoning: Just because some flowers are red doesn't mean all roses are red. There are roses of many colors.

input: If John studies hard, he will pass the exam. John passed the exam. Did John study hard?
reasoning: John could have passed for other reasons (prior knowledge, lucky guessing, etc.).

input: Every student in the class has a pencil. Maria is a student in the class. Does Maria have a pencil?
reasoning: If every student has a pencil and Maria is a student, Maria must have a pencil.

input: If it's Tuesday, then the library is open. It's not Tuesday. Is the library closed?
reasoning: The library could be open on other days too. We only know it's definitely open on Tuesday.

input: Some birds can fly. Penguins are birds. Can penguins fly?
reasoning: Just because some birds can fly doesn't mean all birds can fly. Penguins are flightless birds.

input: All mammals breathe air. Whales breathe air. Are whales mammals?
reasoning: While it's true that whales are mammals, this conclusion doesn't follow from the premises alone. Other animals also breathe air.

input: Either it will rain or it will snow. It's not raining. Will it snow?
reasoning: If it's either rain or snow, and it's not raining, then it must be snowing (assuming the either/or is exclusive).

input: If a shape has four equal sides, it's a square. This shape has four equal sides. Is it a square?
reasoning: A rhombus also has four equal sides but isn't a square. Squares also need four right angles.

input: No vegetarians eat meat. Bob eats meat. Is Bob a vegetarian?
reasoning: If no vegetarians eat meat, and Bob eats meat, then Bob cannot be a vegetarian.

input: All doctors are educated. Some educated people are wealthy. Are all doctors wealthy?
reasoning: Just because some educated people are wealthy doesn't mean all educated people (including doctors) are wealthy.

input: If the alarm rings, there's a fire. The alarm is ringing. Is there a fire?
reasoning: This is valid modus ponens: if P then Q, P is true, therefore Q is true.

input: All prime numbers greater than 2 are odd. 7 is odd. Is 7 a prime number greater than 2?
reasoning: While 7 happens to be prime, the logic doesn't follow. Many odd numbers (9, 15, 21) are not prime.

input: If Tom is taller than Jerry, and Jerry is taller than Mike, is Tom taller than Mike?
reasoning: Height comparison is transitive. If A > B and B > C, then A > C.

input: Every teacher at this school speaks English. Mr. Smith speaks English. Does Mr. Smith teach at this school?
reasoning: Many people who aren't teachers at this school also speak English.

input: All squares are rectangles. This shape is not a rectangle. Is it a square?
reasoning: If all squares are rectangles, and this isn't a rectangle, it can't be a square.

input: Some politicians are honest. John is a politician. Is John honest?
reasoning: Some doesn't mean all. We can't determine if John is one of the honest ones.

input: If it's a weekday, Alice goes to work. Today is Saturday. Does Alice go to work?
reasoning: We only know she goes to work on weekdays. Saturday is not a weekday, so we can't determine if she works.

input: All tigers are striped. This animal is striped. Is it a tiger?
reasoning: Other animals (zebras, chipmunks) are also striped. This is the fallacy of affirming the consequent.

input: Either the car is red or blue. The car is red. Is the car blue?
reasoning: If it's either red or blue (exclusive or), and it's red, it cannot be blue.

input: All even numbers are divisible by 2. 8 is divisible by 2. Is 8 an even number?
reasoning: While 8 is even, the logic doesn't guarantee this. We'd need the converse (all numbers divisible by 2 are even) which is actually true, but not stated.

input: No reptiles have fur. Snakes are reptiles. Do snakes have fur?
reasoning: If no reptiles have fur and snakes are reptiles, then snakes don't have fur.

input: If Sarah practices piano, she improves. Sarah is improving. Is she practicing piano?
reasoning: She could be improving from lessons, natural talent development, or other factors.

input: All circles are round. This shape is round. Is it a circle?
reasoning: Other shapes (spheres, ellipses, ovals) can also be considered round.

input: Every number divisible by 10 is divisible by 5. 40 is divisible by 10. Is 40 divisible by 5?
reasoning: Valid modus ponens: If P then Q, P is true, therefore Q is true.

input: Some athletes are vegetarians. Mike is an athlete. Is Mike a vegetarian?
reasoning: Some doesn't mean all. We can't determine if Mike is one of the vegetarian athletes.

input: If it's winter, it's cold. It's not cold. Is it winter?
reasoning: If winter implies cold, and it's not cold, then it's not winter.

input: All dogs are canines. All canines are mammals. Are all dogs mammals?
reasoning: Transitive property: If all dogs are canines, and all canines are mammals, then all dogs are mammals.

input: Either we go to the beach or the mountains. We're not going to the beach. Are we going to the mountains?
reasoning: In an exclusive or, if one option is false, the other must be true.

input: No fish can live on land. Goldfish are fish. Can goldfish live on land?
reasoning: If no fish can live on land and goldfish are fish, goldfish cannot live on land.

input: If a number is prime, it has exactly two divisors. 15 has more than two divisors. Is 15 prime?
reasoning: If prime implies exactly two divisors, and 15 has more, then 15 is not prime.

input: All successful entrepreneurs work hard. Lisa works hard. Is Lisa a successful entrepreneur?
reasoning: Many people work hard but aren't successful entrepreneurs. This is affirming the consequent fallacy.

input: Some books are bestsellers. Bestsellers are popular. Are some books popular?
reasoning: If some books are bestsellers and bestsellers are popular, then some books are popular.

input: If Tom is older than Lisa, and Lisa is older than Sam, who is younger: Tom or Sam?
reasoning: By transitive property, Tom > Lisa > Sam, so Sam is youngest.

input: All roses have thorns. This plant has thorns. Is it a rose?
reasoning: Many other plants also have thorns (cacti, blackberries, etc.).

input: If you study, you'll pass. You didn't study. Will you pass?
reasoning: You could still pass without studying (prior knowledge, lucky guesses). This is denying the antecedent fallacy.

input: No mammals lay eggs. Platypuses lay eggs. Are platypuses mammals?
reasoning: If no mammals lay eggs and platypuses lay eggs, platypuses aren't mammals (though in reality they are - this shows why premises matter).

input: All triangles have three sides. This shape has three sides. Is it a triangle?
reasoning: While it might be a triangle, having three sides isn't sufficient - the sides must also be connected properly.

input: If it's sunny, we'll go to the park. It's sunny. Will we go to the park?
reasoning: Valid modus ponens: If sunny then park, it is sunny, therefore we'll go to the park.

input: Some cars are electric. Electric cars are environmentally friendly. Are some cars environmentally friendly?
reasoning: If some cars are electric and electric cars are environmentally friendly, then some cars are environmentally friendly.

input: All smartphones have screens. This device has a screen. Is it a smartphone?
reasoning: Many devices have screens (tablets, TVs, computers, etc.).

input: If the store is closed, the lights are off. The lights are off. Is the store closed?
reasoning: The lights could be off for other reasons (saving energy during slow hours, broken, etc.).

input: No odd number is divisible by 2. 7 is not divisible by 2. Is 7 odd?
reasoning: While 7 is odd, we'd need to know that all numbers not divisible by 2 are odd, which isn't stated.

input: All apples are fruits. All fruits grow on plants. Do all apples grow on plants?
reasoning: Transitive: All apples are fruits, all fruits grow on plants, therefore all apples grow on plants.

input: Either the door is locked or unlocked. The door is not locked. Is it unlocked?
reasoning: If the door can only be locked or unlocked, and it's not locked, it must be unlocked.

input: Some politicians are corrupt. Some corrupt people go to jail. Do some politicians go to jail?
reasoning: The logic doesn't connect. The corrupt politicians might not be the same corrupt people who go to jail.

input: If a student studies hard, they get good grades. Emma has good grades. Did Emma study hard?
reasoning: Emma could have good grades from natural ability, prior knowledge, or other factors.

input: All squares have four sides. All rectangles have four sides. Are all squares rectangles?
reasoning: Actually yes - all squares are rectangles (though not all rectangles are squares). Squares are special rectangles with equal sides.

input: No reptiles are warm-blooded. Lizards are reptiles. Are lizards warm-blooded?
reasoning: If no reptiles are warm-blooded and lizards are reptiles, lizards are not warm-blooded.

input: If the temperature is below freezing, water turns to ice. Water turned to ice. Was the temperature below freezing?
reasoning: In normal conditions, if below freezing then ice, and we have ice, the temperature was below freezing (though technically other factors could freeze water).

input: All birds have feathers. Robins have feathers. Are robins birds?
reasoning: While robins are birds, this doesn't follow logically from the premises alone (though in reality, only birds have feathers).

input: If it rains, the game is cancelled. The game is not cancelled. Did it rain?
reasoning: If rain implies cancelled, and the game is not cancelled, then it didn't rain.

input: Some doctors are surgeons. All surgeons have medical training. Do some doctors have medical training?
reasoning: If some doctors are surgeons and all surgeons have medical training, then some doctors have medical training.

input: All metal conducts electricity. Copper conducts electricity. Is copper metal?
reasoning: While copper is metal, other materials also conduct electricity (salt water, plasma, etc.).

input: No vegetarian eats chicken. Mark eats chicken. Is Mark a vegetarian?
reasoning: If no vegetarian eats chicken and Mark eats chicken, Mark is not a vegetarian.

input: If a shape has three sides, it's a triangle. A pentagon is not a triangle. How many sides does a pentagon have?
reasoning: If three sides implies triangle, and pentagon is not a triangle, it doesn't have three sides (it has five).

input: All prime numbers except 2 are odd. 5 is prime. Is 5 odd?
reasoning: If all primes except 2 are odd, and 5 is prime (and not 2), then 5 is odd.

input: Some athletes are vegetarians. Some vegetarians are healthy. Are some athletes healthy?
reasoning: The logic doesn't connect. The vegetarian athletes might not be the same vegetarians who are healthy.

input: All cars have wheels. This vehicle is not a car. Does it have wheels?
reasoning: Just because it's not a car doesn't mean it doesn't have wheels. Bicycles, trucks, motorcycles all have wheels.
